title: british cover up nuclear tests
story: Heres how the British Establishment covers up a scandal, in the most devious way possibleSuccessive governments have hidden the data on cancers and early deaths in survivors of Cold War radiation experiments for decades, says Fleet Street FoxMedia and officials on HMS Alert in May  to witness the Grapple X bomb - they were at a safer distance than most of the servicemen, protected by flash suits and sunglasses while armed forces had little or none. Observers went home afterwards, while the troops lived in the fallout at Christmas Island for up to a year Image: MirrorpixopinionByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  Feb |commentsSeventy years ago this October, Britain detonated its first atomic bomb. The  further nuclear weapon trials ious governments conducted over decades are the reason why, today, Vladimir Putin probably isnapost going to irradiate the UK by teatime. And for the past  years, the servicemen who delivered our nuclear deterrent have been saying they got cancer as a result. That their wives miscarried repeatedly. That children were born with defects - deformities, poor plumbing, extra teeth.To every complaint, each government said the same: there is no evidence. Until Thursday morning, when, just as Putin rolled his tanks into Ukraine, officials published an update to a government study into the health of the nuclear test veterans.  Read the full story of Britainaposs nuclear tests at DAMNED And for the first time it said they were right. They are more likely to die and get cancer. Seven decades after developing a weapon always intended to be physically and genetically devastating to any living thing exposed to it, government scientists admitted that a long-term detrimental health effect associated with participation in the tests cannot be completely ruled out.It took a day to digest the -page report, packed with statistical tables, but the figure which jumped out was that test veterans were . times more likely to die from chronic myeloid leukaemia, a type of bone cancer that, the report says, is radiation-inducible. A further  pages of supplementary material establishes % of the crew of HMS Diana, a warship ordered twice to sail through fallout, had died, almost all from tumours. They show that RAF ground crew who washed down planes that had flown through the mushroom clouds were  times more likely to die from leukaemia. Read moreAnd, perhaps most devastatingly for all those governments which twisted reality and logic to deny these men the truth, suicide rates were excessive in every single decade since the tests began. But something wasnapost right. " target"_self" rel"nofollow"This study began in , with updates in  and . They backed up the government line to such an extent veterans called them a cover-up and whitewash. The new one was ordered in , after the Mirror launched a medal campaign. The authors say the extra  years made it possible to study in more detail and with greater statistical certainty the potential lelong health impact of test participation. Yet on page , the report compares all this extra information with studies from before : reports which do not have that detail. How was it possible, we asked the researchers, to compare, when this is the first time weaposve seen it  We were told that the previous three reports were summary papers, and published alongside them at the same time were companion reports with extra data. Veterans, families, campaigners, lawyers, and war pension advocates were amazed. This was the first time they had been told the first  studies were summaries, and that there was anything extra. We asked when and where these companion reports were published. We were told they all have ISBN numbers, and were available from government agencies. And they were mentioned in the summaries.With the latest study, all  have now been put online. So we had a look at the first, which was only ever available previously in paper format. It was  pages long, and published in the British Medical Journal on January , . Nowhere within it does it state that there is extra detail in a companion report.What there is, is a footnote. It could be identied as the right reference only because it mentions a code also used on the front page of the companion report. This report could be found onlyyou already had it. This footnote is referenced in the paper just twice, and says merely that the companion report describes methodology and verication checks. There is no mention, whatsoever, of it containing DATA . But this extra information is eye-opening. Spread across  pages, it shows test veterans are . times more likely to die from leukaemia, . times more likely to die from bladder cancer, and raised rates of suicide. And thereaposs a table showing  test veterans dead from chronic myeloid leukaemia, compared to none in the control group, a statistically-signicant figure with a low rate of probability, which means men at the nuclear tests were  TIMES more likely to get a radiation-inducible bone cancer than anyone  in the population.A call to the Stationery Office established that not one copy of this companion report had even been published, not once in  years.  It is entirely possible, therefore, that you are one of the first people in the world to ever see what the British state has known for most of your le: that men ordered to take part in experiments weaponising radiation were more likely to die as a result.Despite knowing that, the state fought every war pension claim and court case. It issued denials to every Daily Mirror story. It sent ministers to the Despatch Box to say there was no evidence. It did it all using millions of pounds of taxpayersapos money - your money.Thousands of test veterans have died, uncompensated and unrecognised, because no-one told them about the companion reports. Hundreds of thousands of children have been born to parents who ask a doctor why, and the doctor just shrugs, because this data was hidden in the footnotes. Decades have rolled slowly by while whole families of men who served their country went in and out of hospital, lost jobs, lost faith, and grieved for those who took their own lives. Ministers were briefed by advisers, who read the reportaposs front page which blames smoking and says that, overall there was no detectable effect on health from the tests. Editors and defence reporters in a once-angry media listened to briefings from the MoD, and shrugged the story away. Read more Even veterans and lawyers, who pored over these documents, had no reason to think there was proof within them that radiation-linked bone cancer could be linked to explosions of plutonium isotopes that have been considered toxic and bone-seeking almost since their discovery. Yet here it is, hidden in the open, unpublished but publishable, something that has never existed in physical form and which can be seen only to those whoaposve seen it already. It takes a special level of deviousness to cover something up while at the same time covering your own arse to effectively hide something in a microdot, so that you can always say it was published at the time.It could be argued that the passage of time has made the test veteran data clearer, and the figures worse. As some of these illnesses are more common with age, there is a clearer comparison with the control group. But it is indisputable that at least those  men who died from radiogenic bone cancer within  years of the tests could have had a war pension from the moment they fell ill. Their widows,they were married, could have had a pension too they could have had faith. Instead they were denied even a medal by a state which puts itself above the people it serves.It would have cost us two things: a fraction of the money spent fighting the veterans, and the pride of an Establishment which is simply unable to admit it ever did wrong. Both would have been worth paying, and weaposd have a finer country for it. One which, perhaps, that would never have let a despot who puts radiation in a pot of tea be in a position to invade anywhere. title: dwp man who cant walk
story: DWP: Man who cant walk or speak faces losing adapted car midway through High Court fightThe mum of Cameron Mitchell, , from Carlisle, has been given permission to challenge DWP PIP benefit rules in the High Court. But he could lose his Motability car before the case is even heard by a judgeCameron Mitchell and mum Nicola Clulow, who has launched a court challenge over a DWP ruleByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA man who can’t walk or speak fears losing his adapted car midway through a High Court battle over his disability benefits. Cameron Mitchell, , from Carlisle, suffers frequent seizures and muscle spasms and is fed through a tube, according to his lawyers Leigh Day.But his Personal Independence Payment, and his mothers’ Carer’s Allowance, were stopped because he spent  days in hospital to June last year. PIP is worth up to £. a week to help with the costs of being disabled. But it is only paid for the first  days of a stay in a care home, hospital or prison. Cameron’s mum Nicola Clulow was given permission last week to fight a High Court judicial review against the -day rule, which her lawyers say breaches human rights law on discrimination. But while the battle is ongoing, the family have faced demands tohis PIP-funded Motability car.  While the Department for Work and Pensionsagreed to stop clawing back overpayments for at least six months, the mobility element of his PIP - used to fund the car - was still clawed back in late . They were initially asked tothe Motability car by this Thursday. After the Mirror intervened, Nicola was told the date had been extended to June . But that would still be before the High Court hearing in Cameron’s case, which is currently due on June . Lawyers say Cameron is spending half his week in a care home and half in hospital and needs the car to get between the two. His mum Nicola said: “Heaposs  years old and has had to spend days and nights for months watching very sick people who often donapost survive. “Despite his lack of communication, itaposs clear to everyone that he was switching off from the world, was depressed and just had no interest in le.“Contact with the outside world and the ability to go home to be with family are crucial for him. “To go out, and especially to go home, Cameron requires a great deal of equipment to go with him and this would be impossible without his Motability car.“Having been called on  February  by Motability to say his vehicle must be ed on Thursday  March was one of the most dficult and upsetting situations we have faced.“It means that Cameron will once again have to simply stay looking at the four walls of the Intensive Care unit and not get home.”DWP officials argue the -day limit is a long-standing rule that stops people being funded twice at the same time, by the NHS and the benefit system.But Nicolaaposs case is backed by evidence from Mencap, Carers UK and Marie Curie.She argues that even though Cameron was in hospital, she still needed to provide essential care - including spotting when a seizure was imminent, communicating with him and helping him move around.Leigh Day solicitor Carolin Ott said: “We are very pleased that the court has granted our client permission for a judicial review of the hospitalisation rule which has suspended his PIP and his mother’s Carer’s Allowance. “But [we] are deeply concerned by the detrimental impact of the enforcement of the rule whilst Cameron awaits his day in court.“Cameron is a young man with profound and multiple learning disabilitiesand like many others with PMLD is dependent on input from his known carers.“In circumstances where the NHS alone can’t cover his care needs, his PIP should have never been suspended in the first place.” A Motability spokesperson said: “Should the DWP decide to suspend a customer’s allowance due to hospitalisation, Motability Operations will make contact with the customer to understand the nature of suspension. “The Scheme is only able to supply cars, powered wheelchairs or scooters to those in receipt of a qualying allowance. “Motability Operations have been supporting the Clulow family, however given the exceptional nature of this case and the ongoing legal review, Motability Operations will be contacting Mrs Clulow to discuss what further support they may be able to offer given the family’s current inidual circumstances.” A DWP spokesperson said: “We do not comment on live litigation.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSDepartment for Work and PensionsCameron MitchellHospitalsCare homesHuman rightsNursing homes" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: licence required carry out botox
story: Licence required to carry out botox and fillers under new government plansHealth Secretary Sajid Javid said far too many people have been left emotionally and physically scarred when things have gone wrong after botox and facial filler proceduresA licence will be required to carry out botox and facial filler proceduresImage: Getty Images EyeEmByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Feb |commentsA licence will be required to carry out botox and facial filler procedures under new plans. The Government is introducing the requirement to protect patients from botched non-surgical cosmetic procedures.Health Secretary Sajid Javid said “far too many people have been left emotionally and physically scarred” when things have gone wrong.The plan will come in an amendment to the Health and Care Bill being tabled tomorrow. The Government believes pressure from social media has contributed to a surge in young adults wanting cosmetic surgery. Mr Javid said: “While most of those in the aesthetics industry follow good practice when it comes to patient safety, far too many people have been left emotionally and physically scarred after botched cosmetic procedures.  “I am committed to protecting patient safety by making it an offence for someone to perform these cosmetic procedures without a licence. “We’re doing all we can to protect patients from potential harm, but I urge anyone considering a cosmetic procedure to take the time to think about the impact on both their physical and mental health and ensure they are using a reputable, safe and qualied practitioner.”The Health and Care Bill has been controversial with unions warning it will be a major reorganisation that will cement the role of the private sector in the NHS.The Government stands accused of a “power grab” as the new bill hands the Health Secretary powers over the day to day running of the NHS. Currently it sets general funding and salary structures but operational decisions are made independently by the NHS leadership.Health Minister Maria Caulfield said the spread of images online via social media has led to a rise in demand for botox and fillers. She added that there had been a subsequent increase in people suffering the consequences of badly-performed procedures. She said: “While these can be administered safely, we are seeing an unacceptable rise in people being left physically and mentally scarred from poorly performed procedures. “Today’s amendment is the next step on the road to effective regulation of non-surgical cosmetic procedures in England.” A public consultation will first be launched to representation from patients and interested parties. It follows new legislation making it illegal to give such treatments to under-s, and banning adverts - including social media - for cosmetic procedures which target people in that age group. news politics matt-hancock-says-broke-covid-"Matt Hancock says he broke Covid guidelines after he fell in loveByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsEx-Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said he broke his own Covid guidelines because he fell in love with his aide. The former Cabinet minister was forced to resign last year after leaked CCTV showed him in a clinch with adviser Gina Coladangelo in his Whitehall office. The footage was taken on May  , when indoor social gatherings of people from dferent households were banned under law and guidance urged people to stay two metres apart and avoid face to face contact.Mr Hancock initially clung onto his job and Boris Johnson was criticised for failing to sack him. But the following day he resigned after admitting he had broken his own Covid guidance. In a y interview with the Diary of a CEO podcast, Mr Hancock said he fell in love and it all happened quite quickly - but insisted he did not break the law. Clad in a navy polo neck, the senior Tory spoke atabout the affair, which brought an abrupt end to his Cabinet career. He said: We fell in love and thataposs something that was completely outside of my control. Of course I regret the pain thataposs caused and the very, very public nature - anybody who has been through this knows how dficult it is, how painful it is. Mr Hancock said he fell in love with Ms Coladangelo - whom he has known since his student days - while they were working together at the Department for Health and Social Care. He left his we and children to start a relationship with Ms Coladangelo, who was also married with children. The West Suffolk MP said: It all happened quite quickly, It actually happened after the rules were lted, but the guidance was still in place. So I’m not trying to claim that, I hold no bitterness about this because I broke the rules, I fess up, I broke the guidance.” He went on: “I resigned because I broke the social distancing guidelines by then. They weren’t actually rules. They weren’t the law. But that’s not the point. The point is they were the guidelines that I’d been proposing. And that happened because I fell in love with somebody.”  Mr Hancock admitted to breaking his own guidance when he dramatically quit his Cabinet post last year.In his letter to Boris Johnson at the time, he wrote: We have worked so hard as a country to fight the pandemic. The last thing I would want is for my private le to distract attention from the single-minded focus that is leading us out of this crisis.I want to reiterate my apology for breaking the guidance, and apologise to my family and loved ones for putting them through this. I also need be with my children at this time.In a video posted on Twitter at the time, Mr Hancock admitted he had to go, saying: I understand the enormous sacrices that everybody in this country has made, you have made.And those of us who make these rules have got to stick by them and thataposs why Iaposve got to resign. Mr Hancock was also grilled on his handling of the pandemic - and said he would still have taken the job evenheaposd known Covid was coming. “When the really bad stuff happens and you’re in the job, you got to stand up and be counted,” he said. The senior Tory admitted ministers knew that some of the measures they took during the pandemic were very damaging. “The costs of action are huge, the cost of inaction are also huge,” he said. “So we knew when we were sitting around the cabinet table making these decisions that the balance between these two was an enormous unknown. So with an unprecedented virus with very little data, we were essentially doing these things that we knew weaposre going to be very damaging.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CoronavirusMatthew Hancock MP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: senior male tory slammed commons
story: Male Tory accused of ignoring women as MPs vote to block misogyny becoming hate crimePolicing Minister Kit Malthouse was blasted in the Commons for denouncing the proposal which he claimed would not have an impact from a policing point of view.ByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsPolicing Minister Kit Malthouse was slammed in the Commons as MPs voted to block misogyny becoming a hate crime. Mr Malthouse was accused of ignoring women as he can go home without looking over his shoulder while many women canapost. A senior official told the Mirror it was quite ironic the Government were launching a campaign to protect violence against women and girls as MPs blocked a bill to make misogyny a hate crime. MPs voted  to  with a majority , to remove the Lords amendment which had aimed to make misogyny a hate crime. The Policing Minister said a communications campaign called “Enough” to encourage bystanders and peers to report such behaviour to the police.  The campaign launch tonight was received with mixed reviews from leading campaigners, charities and activists working to end violence against women and girls, the Mirror understands.Weeks before MPs voted on the amendments, Home Secretary Priti Patel is understood to have written to MPs demanding they back her bill as too many criminals were getting off with light sentences.Lucy Allan MP for Telford, was the only Conservative MP to vote against scrapping the amendment, to make misogyny a hate crime. MPs shared compelling accounts of abuse and harassment in the Commons. Caroline Noakes told MPs: If weaposre going to go to the Law Commissionaposs recommendations around misogyny and the complications theyaposve highlighted, we should also be looking at public sexual harassment. This feels like a missed opportunity. It absolutely matters. If weaposre going to start tackling the cultures that underpin male violence to women. Siobhan Baillie Tory MP for Stroud supported Ms Noakes and added: We have to recognise the calls for these changes are from young girls experiencing really tough times everywhere.  Labour MP Stella Creasy said police forces had found it helpful to record data on sex or gender acting as a motivating factor for crimes, including on recognising patterns of behaviour. “Many women will have experienced sexual harassment. They’ll have experienced abuse online, offline in our daily lives to such an extent it infuses what we do. “The flinch when you come out of a tube station to make sure there’s nobody behind you, carrying your keys in your hand, worrying about what your daughter is wearing, hoping that your son isn’t one of those people who does it.” Ms Creasy also said: “The problem for the minister is he says he listens to women, he knows women, he understands this area. Buthe understands at all he should listen to the suffragettes who told us it was deeds, not words that matter.  And all we’ve heard tonight is words. Buthe continues to ignore women,he continues to say that he understands the challenge, to blame them for not coming forward and report things … he’s right to shake and thrash his head, but he can probably go home without looking over his shoulder. Many of us can’t.” In the same session, the Government voted against plans to make it easier to prosecute landlords who take sex for rent from vulnerable Brits. The Mirror revealed the Government would block the amendment passing through which Shadow Home Secretary Yvette Cooper blasted as sickening Shadow Home Office minister Sarah Jones said: “I would urge the House to consider two amendments in this grouping which the Government is tonight rejecting which would make a real dference to women’s lives.”The controversial Bill was torn apart by peers, including the proposals from the Government designed to combat the protest tactics adopted by groups including Extinction Rebellion and Insulate Britain.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyLiberal DemocratsHome OfficePriti PatelKit MalthouseSarah JonesCrimeDomestic violencePoliticsHate crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: vlad invaders nuclear trigger talks
story: © Martin Rowson." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Ukraine will prove fatal, Kevin Maguire says Image: Martin RowsonopinionByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  Feb |commentsPariah Putin’s paranoid desperation is increasingly dangerous yet tightening global strangulation should finally signal the end for this Kremlin crackpot. Ukraine will prove the fatal, final mistake by a fascistic gangster who egotistically believed his own invincible propaganda after strategic triumphs in Crimea and Syria, and the  Trump and Brexit blows delivered to the US and UK. Vlad the Invader’s twitchy finger on the nuclear trigger and the offer of Potemkin negotiations are both signs even he fears this is an impending personal Armageddon. This is fuelled by brave Ukrainians fighting heroically and Russians courageously protesting “No to War”, which is inspiring resistance around the world. Supplying anti-tank, helicopter and aircraft missiles strengthens defenders and weakens attackers already suffering punishing losses. Britain, the rest of Europe and the US finally uniting over economic and cultural sanctions will eventually bankrupt the Putin machine and perhaps drive a deep wedge between the tyrant and his billionaire cronies who enjoy opulent luxury wherever they please.  And China abstaining instead of vetoing a UN Security Council motion by the US condemning the brutal invasion emphasised Putin’s isolation, as a new ally quickly distanced itself from an ageing, deranged dictator. The bloody conflict could still belong: reducing Ukrainian neighbourhoods to rubble, inflicting unbearable heartache and costing countless lives. What is becoming clearer, however, is that Putin is also likely to be one of the victims. But let’s not buy charlatan Boris Johnson’s propaganda that he is suddenly an international statesman, a Prime Minister orchestrating the resistance. Johnson let Putin walk all over him and Britain, with oligarchs smirking unconcerned whenever ruling Conservatives, reliant on Russian-linked money, talked tough then acted soft.Charismatic, cool-headed, defiant Ukrainian Volodymyr Zelensky is what a real leader looks and sounds like. Germany’s centre-Left Olaf Scholz is also rising to the occasion, standing up to Putin at considerable financial expense. A European Union that Johnson ripped Britain from as part of a career move was firmer on sanctions until shamed Johnson started running to catch up. Locking out Ukrainian refugees fleeing terror unless they apply to be fruit pickers is disgraceful and inhuman, when Poland, Romania and Hungary open their borders. Why not seize the spacious British properties of Russian oligarchs to house Putin’s casualties  I’ve watched and known Johnson for longer than the  years Putin has misruled Russia. So I’m aware of the cynicism of the great charlatan. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  The first casualty of war is Partygate, with Johnson relieved that the shells and missiles are effectively providing a smokescreen. If he’s hit by a fine, the PM will pray it is today. Now wouldn’t be the moment to remove a lawbreaker in Downing Street, his apologists will argue. They’d be wrong, of course. Chamberlain was dumped by MPs to be replaced by Churchill during the Second World War then, before Japan finally surrendered, the country swapped Churchill for Attlee. Labour leader Keir Starmer will inevitably receive less airtime than the PM but should have calculated that he must be constructively critical rather than mercilessly pummelling the Tory rogue. War in Europe might save Johnsonnot an invaded country or Putin. title: i pregnant twice 5 days
story: I got pregnant twice in  days - my kids were born on the same day but arent twinsOdalis Martinez, , from San Pablo in Calornia, was over the moon when she fell pregnant after the heartbreak of a miscarriage - but there was another surprise on the wayOdalis couldnt believe she was expecting two girls - but they werent twins Image: KennedyNews ReflectLightPhotographyByNia PriceJessica TaylorReal Le Features Writer:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA mum claims she got pregnant while she was already pregnant - conceiving her two daughters five days apart. Odalis and Antonio Martinez, from San Pablo in Calornia, were over the moon when they found out they were expecting a baby in November , after suffering a miscarriage a few months earlier. But during her first scan, Odalis, , received even more incredible news. She was expecting two babies, conceived during dferent times in the same week. The rare phenomenon is said to occur in .% of pregnancies - while many health professionals suggest it doesnapost exist in humans at all.Odalis said: I was extremely happy that the pregnancy test was positive and we were on our pregnancy journey again.I felt really lucky. I know a lot of people that have been trying to conceive and just havenapost been able to so that was also a fear of mine but thankfully that wasnapost our case and I fell pregnant really quickly. For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here However, after suffering heartbreak from her miscarriage just four months earlier, the mum admits she was worried. It was pretty terrying throughout my whole pregnancy not knowingthat was going to be the outcome again, she said. Hoping for the best but knowing thereaposs always a possibility that things might not go as planned.Recalling her first scan, Odalis said she had to go in alone while Antonio, , waited outside due to Covid restrictions.She said: I was just so scared that they were going to tell me aposoh, thereaposs no heartbeatapos so I was so anxious the whole time I was texting Antonio like aposIaposm so scaredapos. The doctor comes in and Iaposm trying to mentally prepare myself for anything and when she found the first baby and the heartbeat I was crying with so much happiness. And then she started going back and forth and I was wondering why - my mind just went to the worst-case scenario because of the traumatic experience that we had. Thataposs when she told me that she had found another baby that also had a heartbeat. I was just crying with happiness. I felt like the first baby that we had lost was in the room with me and saying it was going to be ok.  She claims the doctor then told her something remarkable - that her babies werenapost technically twins and had been conceived five days apart. The mum-of-two said her due date was set in the middle - two days after one baby would have been  weeks and two days before the other one would have been  weeks. And on  August , babies Lilio and Imelda arrived safely, weighing lbs oz and lbs oz respectively. Odalis said: I feel like itaposs some sort of miracle that I experienced this double pregnancy. Because of our first experience, it made everything during this pregnancy feel so much more special and magical.  Just how easy I was able to conceive, and knowing that I had two babies, I just felt like there was so much light after such a dark place. It was the best surprise ever. It was a really beautul moment to finally be able to hold them in my arms. The full-time mum said the girls are a blessing - but admits the pair look so similar, she and Antonio sometimes mix them up. In fact, the duo look so alike that Odalis says she tells people they are twins rather than explaining how they were conceived.Theyaposre technically not even identical but everyone thinks that they are. They definitely look a lot alike, she said.Antonio will have a baby for an hour and be like aposoh Liloapos this and that and Iaposm like aposyou have Imeldaapos and he will be like aposwhat apos and Iaposm just there laughing because he was like aposoh my God for a whole hour I thought I had Liloapos.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON PregnancyMiscarriageTwins" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: aldi refused mum buy supplies
story: Aldi refused to let mum buy supplies to help Ukrainian refugees due to ‘lack of stockAngela, a -year-old mother of two from Southend-on-Sea, said she went to her local Aldi on Sunday afternoon to purchase sanitary pads, wet wipes and nappies to take in as donationsMs Casey and her friend were only allowed to buy £. worth of items, while the rest of their haul was ed to the shelves Image: Getty ImagesByMirror:,  Feb |commentsA mum who attempted to buy a load of nappies and sanitary pads to send to refugees on the Ukrainian border claims an Aldi worker wouldn’t let her, due to a lack of stock. Agata Casey, of Southend-on-Sea, said she made the decision to stock up on supplies to send to Ukrainian refugees at the Polish border after seeing messages on social media about a nearby restaurant collecting donations. The -year-old mother of two said she went to her local Aldi with a friend on Sunday afternoon to purchase sanitary pads, wet wipes and nappies to take in as donations.Ms Casey, a dental hygienist, told The Mail Online the pair had been careful to leave stock behind for other people. However, upon attempting to pay for their items, she claims they were told they were not allowed to buy “all of the stock”. In response, Aldi claimed they offered to bulk order stock for Ms Casey to collect in two days’ time. A spokesperson attributed the workers’ reactions to Ms Casey’s haul to their store policy to try to allow customers to buy “as much stock as possible” - but to ensure there is “enough stock for other shoppers”. Ms Casey and her friend were only allowed to buy £. worth of items, she said, while the remaining stock they had intended to buy was ed to the shelves. Footage captured by Ms Casey’s friend allegedly shows an Aldi worker putting nappies back into a trolley to put back on shelves due to “shortages” in the UK. Ms Casey said the incident made her feel like a “rat” who was “looting” for wanting to buy donations for Ukrainian refugees. She said: “I was asked like a rat to put this back on the shelves because I am looting Aldi in Southend for Ukrainian people and how dare I. This is how it felt.”The inspiration to buy the items for Ukrainian refugees came from a Facebook post on page Polacy W Southend-on-Sea, she said.The appeal said a lorry would be travelling to Poland on Saturday filled with stock to help refugees. It urged people to drop off donations at Polish restaurant Domowe obiady U Babci, such as long-le food, blankets and hygiene items. She had wanted to do what she could to help during the “biggest crisis of our letime”, she said. Ms Casey added that her parents, who live in Kraków, were taking in refugees in a bid to help.  She and her friend had been conscious about leaving some stock behind for other people, Ms Casey said. The mum claimed they only bought several packs of nappies in a handful of sizes. However, she said she could sense “tension” around her from customers and staff after they loaded up the trolley. As the pair were queueing for the till, Ms Casey said there had been an announcement calling a manager. She initially thought something had happened with the cashier and she would have to move queues, but then realised it was because of her purchase. She claims she was then told by the manager that she could not buy the amount of stock they had selected and would have tosome to the shelves. Explaining her confusion over the debacle, Ms Casey said it wasn’t as though there was a shortage, as there had been during periods of the pandemic. Determined to gather more stock, Ms Casey said she went to Lidl afterwards, where she was told she was allowed to buy nappies in larger quantities. She also went to Farmlands to pick up long-le food supplies and encountered no issues with buying large quantities of groceries.Ms Casey said the experience left her wanting to “cry”, and said she was just trying to do “everything” she could to help the Ukrainian refugees fleeing the country amid Russia ’s invasion.She said: “I just felt unwelcome, I just felt like crying in the middle of that shop. title: civil service jobs salary perks
story: The Civil Service is recruiting - perks include pension, hols and flexible workingYou could step into an exciting new job that matches your skillsAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Feb  There’s never been a better time to join the Civil Service – and with a huge range of vacancies, you might be surprised by the array of jobs on offer – and where.If you think the Civil Service is based only in London, think again. From accountancy and law to security and medicine, you can choose from  types of recognised profession, each offering career routes, and training and development programmes to help you get the best out of your work – plus networking opportunities.The Civil Service has a mission to truly represent the people it serves and particularly welcomes applications from under-represented groups. And job benefits include flexible working, annual and parental leave, and pensions.Soa career with the chance to make a dference to people’s lives beckons, find your next job at civil-service-careers.gov.ukaposI’ve had a lot of support from othersapos I was born and brought up in Tanzania and I came to Wales to finish my education in . I joined HMRC as an adminis­trative assistant in  – never in a million years would I have thought I’d still be here  years later. But I worked with people I really admired and made good friends. When I started out it was all about admin tasks like filing and sending the brown envelopes people hate. But I was quickly promoted and I learned so much. In March  I was promoted to my current role as customs fraud lead in the Fraud Investigation Service [FIS]. I only manage four people and we’re never going to be glamorous – there are no dawn raids or exciting seizures. The aim is for our team to use our knowledge to lead the FIS to serious customs fraud. I was lucky enough before the pandemic to be part of a team that travelled to Namibia, Madagascar and Tanzania to share how HMRC approaches customs risk. We were presenting to each country and listening to the experiences of their tax authorities. For me it was an amazing opportunity to see how our counterparts work. I’m also customs race lead in Wales. In the past couple of years I’ve really centred my attention on ensuring equality of opportunity for colleagues. In Cardf we’ve set up mentoring, coaching and sponsorship with help from senior leaders. It’s about  per cent of my job and it’s completely changed my le. I’ve had a lot of support from others and I thought maybe I can support others.aposMy job is just so rewardingapos I was originally planning to study politics at Newcastle, but one day I decided to have a quick browse on the Civil Service apprenticeship website. I’d always wanted to work in government and it seemed such an incredible opportunity. I applied on a bit of a whim and went through the interview rounds, and then did a presentation on why more young people need to get involved in politics – but I never thought I’d get in. At first it was a bit of an overwhelming experience, going into these great buildings. You can’t believe you’re in this position, seeing all these really senior people in this massive government office. It took time to get my head around that, getting off the Tube every day with Big Ben behind me. I’m just a normal person! Now I’ve been working here for three months and it’s been great – although it feels like a lot longer because I’ve learned so much. Being in the centre of the Cabinet Office I get involved in lots of dferent areas, so I’m in the community and engagement team for the central GCS team, working on internal newsletters as well as helping run the social media channels. I get paid a full-time salary and still spend  per cent of my time studying. Before taking the apprenticeship I was worried about not making friends like you do in university. But I am part of a large cohort of apprentices and so have had lots of opportunities to socialise with them. I think about  per cent of apprentices go on to get a job. After this I’d like to do something in climate communications, maybe for another COP [Conference of the Parties]. The apprenticeship is  months and so there’s always the option to go back to universityyou decide that it’s not for you.But I think the vast majority of people decide that it is for them. I think it’s really magical. It’s just so rewarding, knowing that every day you’re working to hopefully benefit people, working to help make changes and save lives. aposNo two days are the sameapos When I tell people I’m a civil servant – in particular for HMRC – I get lots of jokes about being lazy, having nothing to do and can I do anything about their VAT s. I never go into specics about my actual role because I am fairly sure it would leave people baffled, but hopefully my career to date shows the Civil Service can be an incredibly rewarding place to work. I joined the Civil Service in  as a frontline manager for contact-centre advisers dealing with the introduction of tax credits, and also worked in HR for four years. After nearly  years, I gained my G promotion to a senior project manager working on delivering IT projects across the entirety of HMRC. This was followed by a brief secondment to the Northern Ireland Office as a senior policy adviser on EU Exit. I then came back to HMRC and moved across into my current role in January. There’s the opportunity to move into dferent professions, and the plethora of jobs available mean that you can continue to grow and learn from each role. No two days are the same and the people I work with are fantastic.aposIt’s very family friendlyapos One thing that I’ve been pleasantly surprised by is how supportive and inclusive the Civil Service is. Being a working mum to Henry, six, and four-year-old Harriet, I think it’s really important to have some flexibility and bring your whole self to work. It’s very family friendly. I work  hours over a four-day week. My managers were very supportive of my request to work Monday to Thursday. My little girl has some signicant health issues, so having that flexibility is so important to me. Tech is usually male dominated in the private sector, but it’s been a refreshing surprise to find that the balance is much better in the Civil Service. Two female staff above me also do a four-day week, so there’s the opportunity to look at that career trajectory. Here in the government financethere’s a good gender balance, lots of ersity and dferent skill sets that people bring to the team. I think it definitely reflects the people in the country we serve, which is exactly what it should do. The civil service is very good at looking at people’s transferable skills rather than overlooking youyou haven’t worked in the same job before. For me, I like doing a role that adds value in society and I’ll hopefully have a career where I can succeed and get promoted. As a working mother, that’s absolutely possible here. Training opportunities are a real strong point, too – from courses to mentoring. I work hard, but I like having the balance and flexibility. That’s worth more to me than pound notes would be. The Civil Service is a unique organisation and you get to be involved in things that make a dference to people around the country. It’s really quite special.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON HMRCThe TreasuryNorthern Ireland OfficeEducationPensionsSchoolsTaxCivil servantsPublic servicesBenefitsTax CreditsMost ReadRecommended

title: couple deliver baby second time
story: Couple deliver own baby for second time after road works block way to hospitalDominic Lister, , leapt into action when his we Natalie, , went into labour in their campervan but it wasnt their first rodeo - he had already helped her give birth at home three years beforeDominic Lister, Natalie Lister, son Elliot Lister, and baby Alice Lister with their camper van Dominic had already helped deliver Elliot so when Alice was born on the side of the A he knew what to do Image: Tom Maddick   SWNSByAdam DuttonJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A couple delivered their own child by the side of the road after roadworks forced them to pull over on the way to hospital. Dominic Lister, , leapt into action when his we Natalie, , went into labour in their campervan, but it wasnapost their first rodeo - he had already helped her give birth at home three years before.The funeral director calmly helped deliver his daughter Alice, who was born weighing lb oz, in the middle of the A near Nottingham on February . Dominic had done the same Natalie gave birth to their lb oz baby son Elliot at their home in Bingham without medical help in . The dad-of-two, who has worked in the funeral business for  years, said it was special bringing le into the world given it was the opposite of his usual day job.He added: Itaposs certainly very dferent to my day job. Itaposs the opposite to what I do really but I think being a funeral director actually helped with staying calm. My daily role involves me being calm and reassuring. It takes many years of experience. But helping deliver my own child is not something that I ever expected to have to do. To have done it twice is very special. Iaposve been the first person in the world, for a brief moment, to have held them. Teaching assistant Natalie added: It will be such a nice story to tell the children when they grow up, itaposs unique but definitely not what we planned. He certainly upped the dficulty this time. We were in the dark, in the cold outside, both trying not to panic and there was just nowhere to go. But sometimes needs must, and it was four blokes and an RAC man, and you just have to get on with what you have got to do.  The coupleaposs latest drama came after they tried to make it to Nottinghamaposs Queenaposs Medical Centre when Natalieaposs waters broke at around pm. But they faced ersions and roadworks which meant they were left with no choice but to pull over at around .pm before Alice arrived  minutes later. Several workmen and an RAC recovery driver came to the aid of the pair, while Natalie gave birth to Alice in the back of the vehicle. Dominic explained: It was Monday evening, and we were at home. Nat was sat on the sofa and started having a few twinges. Jokingly I said: aposAre you sure this time apos About pm in the evening, Natalie comes in and tells me that her waters have gone so I put everything in the campervan as it was at the end of the drive. We set off to hospital but a road was closed and we were erted as a lorry in front of me went along at what felt like mph.  We go onto the A and that was coned off. We stopped and I was talking to the workmen. She opened the door and she said the baby was coming now. I thought aposoh no, here we go againapos. It was just a case of keep calm and carry on. An RAC truck pulled up and put his warning lights on to make sure we could be seen while the workmen were calling the ambulance team. But there wasnapost enough time. The delivery was smooth and it was just a case of keeping Natalie and the baby as warm as possible.  I upped the dficulty by doing it in the middle of the A. I wonapost be doing it again though, this is the last one. The staff at the hospital jokingly askedI wanted a job as a midwe - but I said I think delivering two is more than enough. Dominic had helped Natalie give birth to their first child Ethan, now two, at home while a  operator talked him through what to do. He added: With Elliot, Nat started having little twinges about   in the morning. I was at home and we thought aposthataposs it, heaposs coming.apos It got to am and then we realised he was on his way.  I rang the hospital and they knew we were coming. I put all the stuff in the car and came back inside. As we got to the doorstep, she said this is happening now. I rang an ambulance and explained the situation. It happened very quickly. The gentleman at the ambulance control centre talked me through what to do. Knowing the ambulance was on the way was good. He arrived at :am and two minutes later the crew arrived. I was a little bit in shock and I never dreamed Iaposd have to do it again. title: dad obsessed horror films builds
story: Dad obsessed with horror films builds creepy enclosures for his  tarantulasSteve Thornton, , has transformed his living room into a horror fans dream, spending £ on homemade horror-movie enclosures for his eight-legged friendsDad-of-six Steve began his spider collection  years ago and he now has a collection of  tarantulas worth £, Image: Steve Thornton  CATERS NEWSBySarah FittockJoe Smith:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |comments A man obsessed with horror films has spent years building tiny horror-inspired enclosures for his  tarantulas.Spider man Steve Thornton, , has transformed his living room into a horror fanaposs dream, spending £, on homemade horror-movie enclosures for his eight-legged friends.The father-of-six began his spider collection  years ago, with his obsession growing ever since, - meaning he now has a collection of  tarantulas worth £,. The wood machinist from Milton Keynes started building the creepy enclosures four years ago and is in the process of building more for all  spiders to have their own terrying homes. Steve said: I watch nothing but horror movies so thought to bring the two together it mixes my two passions.  The enclosures are more the obsession now than the spiders, to be honest. The thing with spiders is that some of them are really quite boring and you never see them. So, I figured thatyou built something really cool, you still have something to look at. My favourite enclosure is the Friday the th one, I think itaposs because itaposs one of my favourite horrors. Iaposm doing the American Werewolf in London, at the minute, itaposs a classic!  The list goes on, whenever Iaposm out people are telling me that I need to do this one, and I need to do that one. Usually when Iaposm finishing one, I have the next two, three, four planned already. Iaposve done a lot of s classics, The Evil Dead, Hellraiser, Elm Street, the Alien films, Michael Myers Halloween. Itaposs quite cool, when youaposre sitting down watching a film in the living room and all the lights are off, itaposs eerie.  As a father of an autistic son, Steve has managed to raise over £ for charity after auctioning some of his enclosures at spider shows in the UK. He said: Iaposve sold a couple for charity work that I do. I build some and auction them off at charities. My little boy has autism, so I did a big thing last year where we did loads of raffles and built an enclosure. They have spider shows here in the UK and we auctioned off an enclosure at one of the shows which was quite cool.  The enclosures do take some time with some taking a couple of months to build. Steve was introduced to the world of spiders after a work colleague revealed his collection. However, Steve still remains fearful of house spiders. Steve said: I got into it through a mate that I worked with. Before I met the guy and went around to his house to see them, I had no interest, and I had a fear of them as well. But theyaposre not like normal house spiders, normal house spiders freak me out which is weird. And knowing that half of the tarantulas I have would rather bite me than do anything  harmful. If one bit you would likely inflict a pain comparable to that resulting from a bee or wasp sting. You would only really have issues If youaposre allergic to bee stings. They are venomous but very mild. After  years Iaposve not been bit yet, a couple of nearlyaposs but Iaposm very careful. Itaposs an obsession! title: dog owners plea pet spends
story: Dog owners plea as pet spends  days in intensive care after eating plastic tableclothTwo-year-old Hufflepuff has racked up a £, vet bill after undergoing a four hour surgery to remove the plastic tablecloth - and is preparing for two more operationHufflepuff swallowed a plastic tablecloth Image: Sue PendaByPaige FreshwaterContent Editor:,  Feb |commentsA desperate plea has been issued after a dog spent  days in intensive care after swallowing a plastic tablecloth. Two-year-old Hufflepuff managed to eat his way through part of the unforgiving fabric when his owner turned her back for just minutes to tend to her foster horse. The bitzer, fondly known as Cockieshitpookie, suffered severe trauma to his intestines and had to undergo a four hour surgery to remove the tablecloth. After spending  days in intensive care with specialist drugs and round the clock nursing care, Hufflepuff racked up £, in vets bills. Thankfully, his insurance covers £, - but his owner has been left with £, to try to cover through her state pension.to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Owner Sue Penda opened her own animal rescue centre in Cornwall more than  years ago, where she cared for and rehomed hundreds of dogs before retiring in .Her friend, Donna Burgess said: Iaposve never known her not be doing something to help somebody. Dogs, horses or cats,they need help, shelter or treatment, sheaposs there for them. She is a responsible owner. All her animals are insured but  gave her the most awful run of poor luck. She nursed and lost three of her dogs to cancer in less than  months. With two of them going beyond their insurance cover, Sue funded their treatment from savings and selling her vehicle. Donna, from, Redruth, Cornwall, has set up a GoFundMe page to support Sue through the costs and help save Hufflepuffaposs le as he prepares for yet another surgery.  The -year-old added: Part of his duodenum couldnapost recover, so he needed another very delicate surgery to remove  inch of his gut and then a third surgery as he developed scar tissue which caused another blockage. A lot of people would have given up but not Sue. It will be years before Sue is clear of the remaining debt, using nothing but her state pension to repay the cost. I would dearly love to raise as much as possible to help towards Hufflepuffaposs vet bill and I would be deeply gratefulyou felt able to contribute. All monies will go directly to his veterinary cost. Sue and Donna have thanked their veterinary team for the awesome treatment they have provided Hufflepuff with throughout his time in their care. He thinks he is jointly owned by all the staff, who all gave much of their time, care and love free of charge,said Donna. I dread to think what the total bill would have been without their generosity. Hufflepuff has been described as a right character who has a vitality for le that is a joy to see.To donate towards Hufflepuffaposs vet bills, visit Donnaaposs GoFundMe page. Do you have a dog story to sell  Email paige.freshwater@reachplc. title: generous brits donate vital supplies
story: Generous Brits donate vital supplies and money to Ukrainian refugees fleeing homeAt a Polish club in south London there were long queues as people lined up to give clothes, bedding, and other essentials to its donation drive helping people fleeing the country into Poland in Balham, south London" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Russian-invasion-of-Ukraine.jpg" width"" "" Donations at the Klub Orla Bialegoin Balham, south London Image: PAByTom ParrySpecial correspondent:,  Feb |comments Generous Britons have donated vital supplies and money for the thousands of Ukrainian refugees arriving across the border.Following appeals for help as families flee their homes in Kyiv and other major cities, there has been a massive outpouring from people wanting to help out.At a Polish club in south London there were long queues as people lined up to give clothes, bedding, and other essentials to its donation drive helping people fleeing the country into Poland.The White Eagle Club on Balham High Road saw people waiting to give what they could as they waited around the block, leaving volunteers with heaps of collections to sort through.  Mountains of donations could be seen piled inside, waiting to be organised by volunteers. One tweet from Basia Cummings said: “The Polish community of south London collecting supplies for Ukrainian refugees. “Overwhelmed with donations. Sorters needed: White Eagle Club, Balham.” Another go get involved was actor Ben Lamb who said it was “amazing” how many had turned out to support those most in need. Dr Rosena Allin-Khan, the Labour MP for Tooting posted: “Am always so proud of our community. “The White Eagle Club on Balham High Road needs more volunteers every day to assist with sorting through the generous donations.”  The venue said the most needed items include batteries, torches, clothing, shoes, nappies, dry sanitary clothes, thermal clothing, gloves, and painkillers. Other necessities are duvets, blankets, sleeping bags and pillows.It comes as the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugeesupdated its estimate on the number of refugees that have left Ukraine, saying the total stands at more than , a figure that continues to rise.The UNHCR said humanitarian needs are “multiplying and spreading by the hour”. The unprovoked invasion of neighbouring Ukraine by Russian forces on the command of President Vladimir Putin has sparked bloodshed and chaos. With Putinaposs troops shelling cities across Ukraine and the nationaposs army vowing to fight to the death to defend their land, observers fear the death toll will be enormous.On Sunday, February , Ukraineaposs health minister reported that at least  Ukrainian civilians have been killed since the Russian invasion began, and more than , wounded. On Monday, February , President of Ukraine Volodymyr Zelensky said , Russian soldiers had been killed so far. He added that  Ukrainian children have been killed and  wounded over the past four days. These claims have not yet been independently veried but a human rights monitoring team from the United Nations has confirmed  civilian casualties in Ukraine, including  deaths, after three days of clashes, a UN report showed on Monday.It said the fighting had triggered severe humanitarian consequences and that casualties could be considerably higher.Meanwhile, UN human rights chief Michelle Bachelet said on Monday that at least  civilians in Ukraine have been killed since Russia launched its invasion last Thursday, with a further  injured, but the real figure is feared to be considerably higher. Bachelet, addressing the opening session of the Human Rights Council in Geneva, said: Most of these civilians were killed by explosive weapons with a wide impact area, including shelling from heavy artillery and multi-launch rocket systems, and air strikes. The real figures are, I fear, considerably higher. The agency said it is sending stock of core relief items to Moldova, including blankets, sleeping mats, family tents, winterisation kits, sleeping bags, water jerrycans, baby kits, solar lamps and other items for at least , people. “UNHCR has launched a Ukraine Emergency Appeal to help with relief efforts, because our relief work relies on donations and the needs on the ground are immense,” it said. “All donations can be made through our UK charity partner – UK for UNHCR. “We are receiving many calls from the UK public offering support and we are hugely grateful to those who have already donated or have already been in contact with us here in the UK offering to host refugees in their home.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON United Nations High Commissioner for RefugeesPublic servicesRussia Ukraine warDaily Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i told terminate baby downs
story: I was told to terminate baby with Downs Syndrome - now I have a remarkable daughterHetty Blakey felt let down by Lincolnshire hospitals and was told to consider changing her address to be closer to specialist care. The trust said it is investigating a formal complaintHetty Blakey and baby Poppy Image: Hetty Blakey   BPM MediaByLauren DavidsonReporterGraeme Murray:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb |commentsA mum says she was told to terminate her pregnancy after her daughter was thought to have Downaposs Syndrome.Mum Hetty Blakey gave birthday to Poppy in November, but says she feels let down by Lincolnshire hospitals over her daughteraposs care.She also claims she was told to consider changing her address to be closer to specialist care for her. The trust has confirmed it is investigating a formal complaint and is liaising with Poppyaposs family. Along with feeling pressured into terminating her pregnancy, Hetty also claims he was told by a heart consultant that she could not see her daughter, who was at risk of heart failure. She says Poppy was given the wrong immunisations, leaving her daughter bleeding from her behind and spending time in AE.Hetty had her initial  week scan at Lincoln County Hospital. She told GrimsbyLive: From the scan, we were given a leaflet on abortion and told that it didnapost look good, and that with the amount of [nuchal translucency] fluid, there was a chance that the baby had something very severe. They handed me a scan picture and lulled me into this really depressed place of, aposThis babyaposs not going to liveapos. That was before any diagnosis was made. It was just purely off of a scan. All babies have this fluid at the back of their neck, and in a baby that doesnapost have any chromosome abnormalities, the measurement would usually be between one and two millimetres. But a baby that has a chromosome abnormality, their measurement would normally be above three. So because the thickness was so high - in our case it was .mm - that was enough for us to be handed an abortion leaflet. The couple then sought private healthcare at the Harley Street Hospital in London, and Hetty underwent CVS , a procedure which detects foetal abnormalities. It was there that she was told her unborn baby had Downaposs Syndrome.She continued: [The baby] looked perfectly healthy and they didnapost feel there was a reason to medically terminate the baby at all. Hetty said that in the first week after hearing the news, she felt like her baby was gone. She said: I had feelings of embarrassment, shame, and I thought that I was going to be laughed at.Me and my partner were really upset, but it mustaposve taken about seven days for us to snap out of it and get things organised, and just fall in love with the pregnancy again.Hetty said that she would have made the decision to terminate the pregnancy had she followed the advice given at Lincoln Hospital and not sought a second opinion. She continued: I wouldaposve aborted Poppy based on the information I was given at Lincoln Hospital. They made it feel like it was the most fair thing to do. It was not a case of, aposShe might have something wrong with her, but it could be OKapos, there was no happiness to it. It was just very much a case of, prepare yourself. I felt really hurt and disregarded. I drove on a bypass absolutely hysterical, alone, because my partner was in London that day. But I was incredibly suicidal. After that day, they never contacted me again. I was not even called to seeI was OK, she claimed. Poppy was nearly not here as a result of their advice. It was after the diagnosis that the expecting couple decided to move to Kirmington, on the outskirts of Grimsby, and their care was transferred to the Diana, Princess of Wales Hospital.Hetty also suffered with polyhydramnios, a rare condition in which there is an excessive amount of amniotic fluid. A heart defect in her unborn baby was also detected, something which occurs in around half of all Downaposs Syndrome babies - along with duodenal atresia, a condition in which the stomach is not attached to the bowel. At this point, we were classed as a very high-risk pregnancy and Grimsby could no longer deliver Poppy, Hetty said. The couple were referred to two dferent hospitals: Leeds Childrenaposs Hospital for Poppyaposs heart defect, and Sheffield Childrenaposs Hospital for Poppyaposs duodenal atresia. They were also sent to Scunthorpe General Hospital for foetal medicine. At  weeks pregnant, Hetty had to choose between giving birth at Grimsby hospital and being taken in an ambulance two-and-a-half hours away to Leeds, or move where for the remainder of her pregnancy. She said: [Going in an ambulance] ran the risk of,anything happened with Poppy, she wouldnapost have the specialist care right there, and there wouldnapost be anyone who could work on her heart immediately. So we had to basically up and move. Hetty looked online and found a hospital in London which specialises in unborn babies with Downaposs Syndrome.  She said: I was told at  weeks that the baby could come at any time, and I was told that I needed to move to London and needed to move there quick. The couple were told they had to be within walking distance of the hospital, and say they were forced to spend £, on hotels that were close by because the care Hetty and Poppy needed was not available in Lincolnshire. They eventually found an apartment across the road from St Thomasapos Hospital, where Harriett had to lay in bed for five weeks as a result of her polyhydramnios until Poppy was born. Poppy was born via emergency C-section, and Harriett said that had she not been at a hospital with specialist care available, she does not believe her daughter wouldaposve survived.  Returning home to Grimsby after Poppy underwent two surgeries, the family had been told that St Thomasapos Hospital in London would now be sharing the responsibility of Poppyaposs care with the Diana, Princess of Wales Hospital. Hetty says the care Poppy has received at Grimsby Hospital has left her feeling neglected. She said: We asked Grimsby hospitalthey could scan Poppyaposs heart as she had an open duct which couldaposve led to immediate heart failure. We were told that the consultant couldnapost see us. Hetty also claimed that Poppy was also given the wrong immunisations at Grimsbyaposs hospital. Any baby thataposs had operations on their intestines or bowels should not have something called the rotavirus immunisation. That causes sickness and diarrhoea. Poppy shouldnapost have had it, and Grimsby hospital administered it. Two days later, I was at Sheffield AE with Poppy because she was bleeding from her behind. Everything weaposd just gone through was potentially undone by Grimsby hospital, because then Sheffield were talking about a potential third surgery to correct her bowels again. For a mum whoaposs just got her baby out of the intensive care unit, it was incredibly frightening. I feel a huge amount of neglect and I feel harassed and bullied by Grimsby hospital. Iaposve had letters through the post telling me that I havenapost engaged in their services because Iaposve said to them that at the moment, as Poppy has a heart defect, the hip and ear tests they want to do arenapost important. Sheaposs seen by the top cardiologist in London and yet Grimsby hospital feel that they have to put their ten pence in all the time. Iaposm getting letters telling me how to care for my child when Iaposve been left to do this all by myself. Poppy is now awaiting open heart surgery. Hetty said: Poppy is a remarkable little girl. Melanie Sharp, deputy chief nurse at Diana, Princess of Wales Hospital in Grimsby said: “We are fully aware of these concerns and currently we are investigating as a formal complaint. We’ll respond directly to the family once the investigation has concluded.”A spokesperson for the United Lincolnshire Hospitals NHS Trust said: “Unfortunately we are unable to comment on inidual cases, however, we have been contacted by the patient’s family and have been liaising with them directly.”Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesHospitalsPregnancyDowns syndrome" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: locals bemused towns tiny parking
story: Locals bemused by towns tiny parking spaces which barely fit half a carSome motorists said the spaces have always been annoying, but others askedthe parking slots were supposed to be used sideways and found them amusingThe car parks tiny spaces Image: SubmittedByKatie TimmsReporterGraeme Murray:,  Feb |commentsMotorists are bemused by new parking spaces in a town centre that can only fit half a car.The short stay car park has become a hot topic on a Facebook group and caused hilarity because the spaces would only fit a tiny vehicle at a squeeze.One man joked that people needed a little car to park there and the spaces have left drivers baffled. Some said the spaces aposhave always been annoyingapos, but others askedthe parking slots were supposed to be used sideways. PlymouthLive reports that it asked Cornwall Council about the spaces but it failed to respond. The title said: We asked Cornwall Council, but after no response we went to check out the spaces ourselves and can confirm that the width is too small to fit a car sideways too. The remainder of the car park has full-sized spaces, but they are along the wall and are are smaller than the others. Some people joked that parking wardens may give you a ticket for not staying in the lines. Another added: Does this mean you only have to pay half the parking fee  But others pointed out the smaller spaces might be used for motorbikes and smart cars. Readers of Cornwall Live were bemused by the spaces, with some offering ideas on how to fix the situation. One user wrote: “Parking charges should reflect the space occupied by a vehicle. The larger the vehicle, the higher the rate. “This would encourage people to drive smaller cars around towns to park while the aposCha tractorsapos would have to pay much more. Another said: “They probably forgot to bring a measuring tape.” Cornwall Council, says drivers can use the car park for £. per week, but this doesn’t guarantee a space - even a tiny one. It doesn’t appear to offer a discountthe motorist can only fit half their car in a space.The authority does stat, however, that motorcycles can park for free, which one poster suggested was to why the spaces are so small. And its website states the spaces should be designated. According to the British Parking Association off-street bays should be . metres wide by . metres long. It adds: These dimensions are neither minimum nor written in tablets of stone, and may be revised to suit your particular needs, but remember that good access and wider bays aids efficient use of the parking area, Some car parks are now designed with a thick coloured outline around the bays, an area to enable better access. title: mum suspended job after offering
story: Mum suspended from job after offering sex at Christmas party says she was spikedMichelle Hosking, , is the subject of a gross misconduct investigation and has been temporarily dismissed from her duties as a health and safety advisor at Bournville Village TrustMichelle says the handling of the incident and the spiking itself has affected her mental health Image: Nick Wilkinson BPM MEDIAByStephanie BallooHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Feb Updated:,  Feb A mum suspended from her job after she became possessed and offered sex at a work Christmas party says she was spiked by injection. Michelle Hosking, , is now the subject of a gross misconduct investigation and has been temporarily dismissed from her duties as a health and safety adviser at Bournville Village Trust, where she has worked for  months. The single mum-of-two allegedly switched before colleagues, who accused her of propositioning them for sex and suddenly becoming mental and possessed.But Michelle insists she was spiked, claiming she discovered a visible pinprick and developed a huge bruise after the work do on December  in Birmingham city centre, Birmingham Live reports.After losing hours of her memory from the party, Michelle reported the spiking incident to West Midlands Police and attended hospital the following day. But three days later, the mum was suspended from her role as the Trust launched an ongoing probe and said it took the allegations of spiking and misconduct very seriously. Michelle said: I used to love working for them but the way they have treated me is horrendous. I can understand how these other girls are feeling because you donapost expect it to happen to you and when it does, no oneaposs there for you and the people that do [the injecting] donapost understand what happens behind the scenes. Iaposm a single mum Iaposve got two children, Iaposve got a mortgage to pay. If the spiking is for laughs, itaposs for laughs but itaposs not for the people that are involved in it. I keep having to ring up and ask the question to my employer and they say itaposs still under investigation. Itaposs nearly three months now and obviously the mental health impacts of that as well as everything that happened before, itaposs horrendous. Michelle can remember eating her starter and having a glass of wine before three more apostinyapos drinks. She then claims she lost four hours after she was spiked walking from the Old Joint Stock pub to the main venue, the Clayton Hotel. She said: I do believe I was spiked by injection. Unfortunately my employers have taken a very dim view of it and Iaposve been suspended on full pay ever since. I remember eating my starter then Iaposve lost four hours, she continued. I just donapost remember. The witness statements say that I was being aggressive, waving my arms around, I was possessed, I was mental, I was psychotic and I have no recollection of this at all. Itaposs almost like a switch was flicked, itaposs gone. Thereaposs nothing there at all, I have no recollection at all. They said I was acting crazy, mental, possessed. Allegedly, obviously I donapost remember any of this, allegedly I punched a colleague, I propositioned a few people for sexual relations, I was in a relationship at the time so I canapost understand why that would happen.  Michelleaposs next memory is getting home at .pm, when she rang colleagues in a confusion over what had taken place and why she was back at her house so early on into the festivities. She said: Something wasnapost quite right, I rang a couple of colleagues and said: aposWhat happened apos A couple of colleagues brought me home in a taxi. Michelle described the following months as horrendous as she claimed colleagues had been told not to speak to her, leaving her completely and utterly isolated. The last three months have been awful. I havenapost heard from my line manager since the December  when he suspended me, no duty of care was carried out. Itaposs been horrendous. I had a massive bruise on my thigh. You can see the pin prick marking my leg in the photo. On Tuesday afterwards, I went to the hospital as my sister said she didnapost like how the bruise was spreading. Michelle has hit out at the offenders using needles to spike revellers as she spoke of the impact on her mental health. She said: I donapost think people understand the actual impact that something like that can have. Iaposm just a normal mum, I take my kids to school and go to work and then this happens and your whole world implodes but people donapost understand itaposs really hard. It has really affected my mental health. I was on antidepressants for anxiety before this, so the fact that Iaposve had no communication is just exacerbating everything. The last time I spoke to them was two weeks today at the disciplinary hearing. They did actually apologise to me for not providing me with that care. I donapost know whataposs going on, no one has rang me. Bournville Village Trust said it takes both reports that a colleague has been harmed and accusations of misconduct very seriously as it said investigations take time to complete. The Trust said it could not comment on the inidual circumstances, but aposoffer support and regular contactapos through investigations. Helen Harvey, director of people and performance at Bournville Village Trust, said: “The health and safety of our colleagues is very important to us and any reports that a colleague has been harmed in any way are taken very seriously and treated sensitively. We also take accusations of misconduct extremely seriously and they are investigated thoroughly and carefully to ensure colleagues are treated with fairness and respect. This means that investigations can take time to complete whilst all evidence is gathered and reviewed. During an investigation, colleagues are offered support and regular contact throughout. As our investigation process is confidential we are unable to comment on inidual cases.” West Midlands Police said in a statement: Our investigation into this crime closed after all lines of enquiry were exhausted. If new information is received that would help us identy the person responsible, we are ready to reopen the case.
